Rafael, our 2002 paper on NEAT does include a comparison with 
Cellular Enc=
oding (CE):

http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/keyword?stanley:ec02

Our 2003 "Taxono=
my for Artificial Embryogeny" paper on indirect 
encodings also includes a =
fairly detailed description of CE and also 
mentions "Edge Encoding," which=
 was proposed to fix some of the 
problems with CE.

http://nn.cs.utexas.ed=
u/keyword?stanley:alife03

CE was an early development encoding and therefo=
re inspired a lot of 
interest in the 90s.  It also was the first learning =
algorithm of any 
type that I know of to solve double pole balancing withou=
t velocity 
inputs.  Another thing that was interesting was that Gruau prov=
ed in 
his thesis that the encoding can produce any graph structure, so it =

is complete.

However, compared to more modern approaches I do not think i=
t is a 
good choice today.  I think the focus was too much on completeness =

and too little on efficiency.  Being complete is not a great 
advantage if=
 it takes too long to find the solution.  In fact, the 
more important issu=
e is *bias*, i.e. to what kinds of structures is 
any particular indirect e=
ncoding biased.  CE seems biased towards 
rigid iterative repreating struct=
ures, including hierarchies.  For 
example, it can solve parity problems of=
 arbitrary arity.  That can 
be impressive, but I don't believe partity pro=
blems are 
representative of most interesting problems.  CE also seems slow=
 in 
terms of # of evaluation to a solution from the reported results.  

A=
ll indirect encodings including CPPNs have some kind of bias towards 
produ=
cing certain kinds of structures.  Usually this bias is good 
fora certain =
level fo complexity.  However, at low complexity, you 
may just want a dire=
ct encoding like regular NEAT.  For example, in 
pole balancing, there is n=
o need for indirect encoding because the 
problem is small, so NEAT will be=
 much faster than CE.

Overall, CE is not in use very much today as far as =
I know and is 
mainly a historical achievement that inspired further work i=
n 
indirect 
encoding.

ken
